case_name: Ellerman Bucknall Steamship Company Ltd. v. Sha Misrimal Bherajee

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 274 of 1964 was filed in the Supreme Court.

issues.text: Did the second defendant act bona fide throughout in issuing the bills of lading and in taking an indemnity from the shippers?

anchor.surface_text: Issue 6 framed by the learned City Civil Judge reads Did the second defendant act bona fide throughout in issuing the bills of lading and in taking an indemnity from the shippers?. The judgment of the learned City Civil Judge discloses that the question of misrepresentation by collusion was argued and the learned Judge held that the Bank was number misled, as under the letters of credit it had to pay the amount against the bills of lading, whether clean or unclean.

holdings.reasoning_summary: False representation in clean bill (omitting 'reused' despite contract for new drums and mates receipt); knowledge via indemnity; intent for LC payment; reliance and damage; analogous to Brown Jenkinson.

holdings.text: A clean bill of lading contains no reservation as to the apparent good order and condition of the goods or the packing; omission of 'reused' renders it unclean when new drums required.

anchor.surface_text: A clean bill of lading is defined in Halsburys Laws of England, 3rd Edn., Vol. 2, at p. 218, as one which does not contain any reservation as to the apparent good order and condition

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies Halsbury and Carver definitions; good order refers to apparent external condition; contract specified new drums.

holdings.text: Clean bill of lading creates estoppel against shipowners denying good order and condition where bad condition discernible on reasonable examination.

holdings.text: New points on ship's mate representation, American law governing bill, and res judicata from US decree cannot be raised for first time in Supreme Court.

precedents.citation: Brown Jenkinson Co., Ltd. v. Percy Dalton  London  Ltd. 1

anchor.surface_text: In Brown Jenkinson Co., Ltd. v. Percy Dalton  London  Ltd. 1  orange juice was shipped in barrels. Some of the barrels were old and frail and some were leaking. Yet the shipowners gave a clean bill of lading.

precedents.case_name: Brown Jenkinson & Co Ltd v Percy Dalton (London) Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: issuing clean bill of lading knowing containers defective amounts to deceit
precedents.cited_holding: shipowners by making in the bill of lading a representation of fact that they knew to be false with intent that it should be acted upon were committing the tort of deceit

precedents.citation: Brown Jenkinson Co., Ltd. v. Percy Dalton  London  Ltd. 1

anchor.surface_text: The decision in Brown Jenkinson Co., Ltd. v. Percy Dalton  London  Ltd. 1  is apposite. There, the defendants had a quantity of orange juice which they wish to ship to Hamburg.
